titleStmt.author: Albertano da Brescia

fileDesc.sourceDesc: Liber Consolationis Et Consilii by Albertano da Brescia. Brescia, 1246. Transcribed from the Thor Sundby 1873 critical edition.

correction.p: Apparent errors in Graham transcription have been corrected using the corr element, resolving any discrepancies with Sundby transcription; because high quality scans of Albertano's book have been uploaded to Google Books, we see no need to record Graham's obvious and unintentional errors.

normalization.p: Punctuation has been modernized to fall within quotation marks, i.e. ," as opposed to ", at the end of a direct quote.
Dipthongs have been separated, i.e. oe instead of œ, ae instead of æ.

quotation.p: Double quotation marks now introduce direct speech, whereas Sundby 1873 critical edition used double quotation marks when characters quoted other sources. Single quotation marks now are used for imbedded quotes by nonbiblical authors.

hyphenation.p: End​-of​-line hyphenation from Sundby transcription has been removed.

interpretation.p: Biblical references are marked in italics.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded for making Liber Consolationis et Consilii accessible online and free to the public.

refsDecl.p: Chapters in the text are numbered with the n attribute; chapters are numbered using arabic numerals. Numbering is consecutive throughout the book. For example: 3 numbers the 3rd chapter of the book.

Each paragraph in the text is numbered with the n attribute according to its respective chapter with the dot as a separation marker. For example: 1.3 identifies the third paragraph of the first chapter.
Citations in the text are numbered with the n attribute. Each number consists of of three digits; numbering is consecutive throughout the text. For example: 001 numbers the 1st citation.

profileDesc.creation: Originally written in 1246 in Brescia, Italy.

div.head: Beginning of the Book of Consolation and Counsel
div.ab: Since there are many who are so afflicted by adversities and weighed down in tribulations, and since they have neither counsel nor consolation on account of their disturbed souls—nor do they expect counsel or consolation from others—they become so distraught that they fall into worse, often evil, circumstances. For this reason, I took care to write down certain teachings for you, Johannus, my son, who heals with the art of surgery. God granting, from the little measure of my knowledge, you will not only be able to grant health to physical bodies, but you will even be able to bless others with counsel, consolation, and aid. Therefore, may you read the following tale zealously and ponder each of the written authorities diligently, and so, with divine grace bestowing, you will easily lead yourself and others in practicing good counsel. Here begins the tale.

div.head: Chapter I
Example in the person of Melibeus
div.p: There once was a certain young man named Melibeus who was rich and powerful. One day he went for a walk, and after closing the front door he left his much-loved wife and daughter at home. Three neighbors, who were also long-established enemies of his, saw that he left and placing ladders entered the house through the windows. Having entered, they violently beat Melibeus’ wife, Prudentia, and also her daughter. They injured the daughter all over, specifically with five wounds: in the eyes, the ears, the mouth, the nose, and hands. Leaving her half-dead, they departed.

Melibeus returned after some time, and once he saw this scene he began to rip out his hair, to let forth an intense moan, and to rend his clothes as if insane. But his wife who had been silent began to upbraid him insistently; still he kept shouting evermore. Having remembered the words of Ovid in his Love’s Remedy, she offered him a little saying:
Who save a fool would forbid a mother to weep
O’er the body of her son? Not then must she be counselled.
When she has shed tears and fulfilled her mind’s distress,
Then may words set a limit to that grief.
Ovid, Remedia Amoris, 127-130.

div.head: Chapter II
On Consolation
div.p:
Once he had held back from crying briefly, grief filled his soul, and Prudentia began to upbraid him saying:
What folly! What madness! Why does this foolish grief oppress you?
Such groans will never gain you reward!
Temper your weeping with prudence and measure,
Dry your tears, and plan what to do.
Pamphilus de Amore, 463-466. Graham's transcription notes the source as Panphilus rather than Pamphilus. Pamphilus de Amore, also referred to as Pamphilus, is a 12th century comedic Latin play in which the protagonist Pamphilus desires the virgin Galatea through a procuress, similar to the one in Ovid Amores Book 1.8. The play was most commonly used by young boys of the Middle Ages for the purpose of learning Latin.
Excessive grief is not a sign of wisdom,
For sorrow returns no profit whatever.
Pamphilus de Amore, 769-770.
“Your daughter, God granting, will be freed from her suffering; for even if she should die, you must not destroy yourself on her account. For Seneca says: The wise man is not distressed by the loss of children or of friends. For he endures their death in the same spirit in which he awaits his own.
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 74.30.
I should prefer you to abandon grief, rather than have grief abandon you; and you should stop grieving as soon as possible, since, even if you wish to do so, it is impossible to keep it up for a long time.”
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 63.12.

Melibeus responded:
“Who in such pain can contain crying and tears, for even our Lord, Jesus Christ, groaned in the spirit and wept for his friend Lazarus.”
John 11:33, 35.

And Prudentia said:
“Temperate weeping is not forbidden for the sad; on the contrary blessed Paul permits weeping when in his Letter to the Romans he says: Rejoice with them that rejoice; weep with them that weep.
Romans 12:15.
And even Tullius says: It is characteristic of the well-ordered mind both to rejoice at good deeds and to be pained at the reverse;
Cicero, De Amicitia, 13.47.
however weeping and shedding many tears is forbidden. Indeed we ought to keep in mind the saying coined by Seneca, who says: Let not your eyes be dry when we have lost a friend, nor let them overflow: we may weep, but we must not wail.
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 63.1.
Before you part with the friend, replace him if you can, for Seneca also says: It is better to replace your friend than to weep for him.
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 63.11.
Accordingly, in order to live prudently send away sadness of this world from your mind entirely, for as Jesus Sirach says: Sadness hath killed many, and there is no profit in it.
Ecclesiasticus 30:25.
And it also said: A joyful mind maketh age flourishing: a sorrowful spirit drieth up the bones.
Proverbs 17:22.
And Solomon says: As a moth doth by a garment, and a worm by the wood: so the sadness of a man consumeth the heart;
Proverbs 25:20.
and again: Whatsoever shall befall the just man. It shall not make him sad: but the wicked shall be filled with mischief.
Proverbs 12:21.
And in his Epistles Seneca says: Nothing is more foolish than to court a reputation for sadness and to sanction tears:
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 99.18.
For none of these things can happen to the sage, that should sadden him: he stands erect under any load,
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 71.26.
just as blessed Job, who—even when he lost all his sons and his status and endured many physical tribulations—always stood tall and gave thanks to the Lord, saying the Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away: as it hath pleased the Lord so is it done: blessed be the name of the Lord
Job 1:21.
from henceforth now and for ever.
Psalms 112:2.
Therefore we must not grieve excessively about children or others we have lost, because what has happened cannot change; but rather we should rejoice about what we have, not grieve about what we have lost, whence someone wishing to console a father about the death of his son says: Do not cry because you lost your good son, but instead rejoice that you had such a son. And elsewhere Seneca also says: Nothing becomes offensive so quickly as grief; when fresh, it finds someone to console it and attracts one or another to itself; but after becoming chronic, it is ridiculed, and rightly. For it is either assumed or foolish.
Seneca, Ad Lucilium Epistulae Morales, 63.13.
And therefore you must certainly cast off temporal despair, for it is true what blessed Paul says in the middle of his Second Letter to the Corinthians: For worldly grief produces death, but the sorrow that is according to God worketh penance, steadfast unto salvation;
2 Corinthians 7:10. Albertano maintains the exact words from the Vulgate but switches the order of the clauses to provide a smooth transition from Seneca’s previous statement about grief to be contrasted with godly grief.
and therefore do not cast off sorrow, but instead take pains to cling to sorrow by day and by night because afterwards your sorrow shall be turned into joy,
John 16:20.
as the Lord says in the Gospel, whence Solomon says, The heart of the wise is where there is mourning, and the heart of fools where there is mirth
Ecclesiastes 7:5.
And again: It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to the house of feasting.”
Ecclesiastes 7:3.

Melibeus responded:
“All that you said is true and useful; nevertheless my soul is so perturbed that I do not know what I should do.”

And she said:
“Call together your true and faithful friends, whether blood kin or not, and diligently seek their counsel about this matter, and then steer yourself according to their counsel. For Solomon says: Do thou nothing without counsel, and He shall not punish thee.”
Ecclesiasticus 32:24.

Melibeus called the abundant multitude of men, blood kin and not; amongst them were surgeons and physicians, old and young, including many neighbors, who respected him from fear than esteemed him with love, and even certain men—now friends once enemies—who returned in gratitude toward him. Many others also gathered there: flatterers, sycophants, and wise legal consultants. Once they had assembled, Melibeus told them everything that had happened to him. And when he asked for their counsel, he indicated a great desire to pursue vendetta within reason.

With the approval of the other surgeons, one of them stood up as representative and said,
“The duty of doctors has always been to look after others, to benefit everyone, and to harm no one. Often it happens that parties in dispute inflict wounds on each other. Doctors should consult their art and administer healing to both parties with attentive care. Therefore, it is neither appropriate for us to give advice on vendetta or feud, nor to take sides; for this reason, we can hardly advise you to pursue vendetta. We have diligently inspected your daughter’s wounds and we will look after her with great attention day and night, and, God granting, even though she may be greatly wounded, we will nourish her to good and restored health.”

After the surgeon spoke, one of the physicians offered him counsel in a similar fashion with the will of his colleagues. He promised Melibeus medical help and on behalf of himself and the other physicians. Concerning feud and vendetta he said:
“as we say in medicine afflictions are healed by their opposites, so too in feud and even vendetta, afflictions are then to be healed by their opposites.”

Melibeus’ neighbors and former enemies—those who had returned in gratitude for him—and the sycophants and flatterers all wore grief on their faces, almost weeping about that which had happened. They counselled him to pursue vendetta within reason and to settle the feud manfully. They commended lord Melibeus both for his power and his wealth, and they numbered the multitude of his kin both of blood and not, of his in-laws and of his friends. They diminished the power of his enemies over him and destroyed their wealth with words.
